iati-activity.title: Building Sector Energy Efficiency Project (BSEEP)
iati-activity.description: Improvement of energy utilization efficiency in Malaysian buildings especially in the commercial and government sectors by promoting energy conserving design of new buildings and improving energy utilization in existing buildings.

iati-activity.title: Building Sector Energy Efficie
iati-activity.description: Building Sector Energy Efficiency (BSEEP) Building Sector Energy Efficiency Project has for its goal the reduction in the annual growth rate of Green House Gas emissions from the Malaysia buildings sector.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To institutionalize a multiple-use forest landscape planning and management model which brings the management of critical protected areas and connecting landscapes under a common management umbrella, implementation of which is sustainably funded by revenues generated within the area

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Conservation of globally and nationally significant biodiversity within project landscape

baseline.comment:
Biodiversity is being depleted at project landscape level, due to habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation
Project landscape currently contains no Class I Protected Forest
Wildlife populations within the project landscape, together with those at adjacent protected areas, are currently estimated at:
A. Elephants 0.5-1.0 Ind/km2
B. Organg utan 0.5-1.0 Ind/km2
C. Sun Bear <1.0 or 3.0 Ind/km2
D. Clouded Leopard <1.0 or 3.0 Ind/km2
However, the baseline and target indicators for wildlife populations are subject to revision based on findings of data gathering and synthesis work to be launched in early 2015. This review will also advise on whether and how (including baseline and target populations) to include Banteng (Tembadau) as an indicator species.
Natural capital being lost through habitat conversion and degradation
Different types of forests in the project landscape:
a. Primary forest 18,517 ha (Note: Primary forest area subject to revision based on findings of data gathering and synthesis sub-contract and incorporated thereafter into the NNL baseline analysis).
b. Secondary forests 242,747 ha

target.comment:
Genetic, species and ecosystem diversity conserved in approximately 261,000 ha. of the Kalabakan-Gunung Rara area, within a sustainably-managed forest landscape of 393,544 ha, including adjacent protected areas
By end of project, at least 500,000 ha of project landscape established as new Class I Protected Forest.
Updated target: 145,000 ha.
A. Elephants 1.0-1.5 Ind/km2
B. Organg utan 2.0-3.5 Ind/km2
C. Sun Bear 2.0 Ind/km2
D. Clouded Leopard 2.0 Ind/km2
No net loss in levels of biodiversity and other ecosystem functions, i.e. full maintenance of natural capital within project landscape over project period, with plan in place for continued maintenance
No decrease in primary forest areas
A 30% increase annual increase in the budget allocation for Class I Protected Forest Reserves
Amended to:
Genetic, species and ecosystem diversity conserved in approximately 261,000 ha. of the Kalabakan-Gunung Rara Forest Reserves, within a sustainably-managed forest landscape of 393,544 ha, including adjacent protected areas.
By the end of the project, at least 145,000 ha of project landscape established and effectively managed as new Class I Protected Forest.
A. Elephants 1.0-1.5 Ind/km2
B. Organg utan 2.0-3.5 Ind/km2
C. Sun Bear 2.0 Ind/km2
D. Clouded Leopard 2.0 Ind/km2
The project seeks as an over-arching target to avoid and minimise impacts on biodiversity, including through plantation development and plans to achieve NNL of biodiversity within the Project area. While on-site mitigation is a strong preference, if this proves unattainable, NNL of biodiversity should be achieved through offsite compensation, e.g. via the conservation of forests neighboring the Project site.
No decrease in primary forest areas

actual.comment:
As reported last year, a land mark decision was made to gazett 95,486 ha of former natural forest management areas within the project landscape as a Class I Protection Forest Reserve. This has increased the Class 1 reserve and conservation areas within the project area from 18,517 ha to 115,673 ha and has exceeded the original project’s target of 50,000 ha, linking three important conservation areas (Maliau Basin, Danum Valley and Imbak Canyon). Nevertheless, in the Inception Report, a new project target has been set at least 145,000 ha by the end of the project. However, as of 30th June, 2015 the total area of Class I Forest Reserves in the project area has increased to 30,627 ha, while the total area under Class VI Virgin Jungle Reserve (VJR) is 4,655 ha. All these forest reserves were gazetted on 24th December, 2014. This means that the total Protected Areas (PA) in the project area as of 30th June, 2015 is 150,955 ha. This has already exceeded the new project target of 145,000 ha.
The commitment of the SFD to pursue the No-Net-Loss (NNL) policy in the State of Sabah and in the project landscape has been reiterated and strengthened. Forest Trends (a consultant group based in USA) has been appointed by the SFD in December, 2014 to undertake a “Policy and regulations Assessment for Implementing NNL/NG of Biodiversity” in Sabah. The final report, which is expected to be finalized in December, 2015 will highlight amongst others the ‘recommendations to inform the drafting of a New Forest Policy and/or changes in existing policies and institutional structures needed to implement these changes’ that ‘focus on:
Implementing NNL/NG of biodiversity
Incorporating biodiversity conservation and ecological functionality into landscape level planning and management for multiple land-uses
Management tools needed for effective implementation (e.g. management agreements, conservation trust funds etc), with the principal elements of implementation guidelines
The role of key stakeholders; and
The government commitments required for this package of measures to work.’
Besides the SFD commitment on NNL policy, biodiversity assessments are planned which will be able to gauge the progress with regard to the species population estimates. In this case, a sub-contract on “Landscape level biodiversity and forest quality assessment and mapping using Lidar and Hyperspectral Imagery” will be awarded to Carnegie Institution for Science USA, while another sub-contract on “Ground based biodiversity assessments (using a range of key taxa), mapping & monitoring programmes” will be awarded to a small consortium of leading scientists.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Level of functionality of biodiversity-friendly, multiple use forest management systems in Sabah

baseline.comment:
Sabah has no functional, biodiversity friendly, multiple use forest management systems
Capacity Scorecard, SFD | YS
A. Enabling environment 64 | 67
B. Leadership 67 | 80
C. Knowledge 56 | 69
D. Accountability 51 | 62
Overall Mean Score 59 | 69

target.comment:
Project landscape is being managed in a manner that demonstrates the technical, economic and financial feasibility of the new management approach
An enabling policy and regulatory environment ready to facilitate expansion / replication of the model (i) to other forest landscapes in Sabah that include (or will include) protected forest reserves, and (ii) to other PA sub-systems in Sabah.
The Sabah Forestry Department and Yayasan Sabah have enhanced capacities and experience with the model needed to enable its maintenance and replication
End of Project target (30% over baseline), SFD | YS:
A. Enabling environment 83 | 87
B. Leadership 87 | 100
C. Knowledge 75 | 90
D. Accountability 66 | 81
Overall Mean Score 78 | 90

actual.comment: The mid-term capacity score assessment will be conducted in the next reporting period. In January 2015, the SFD contracted Forest Trends to conduct on “Policy and Regulations Assessment for Implementing No Net Loss/Net gain of Biodiversity in Sustainable Multiple-use Forest landscape” in Sabah. Results of this will lay a foundation for improved and biodiversity friendly, multiple use forest management systems and provide an enabling policy and regulatory environment ready to facilitate expansion / replication of the model (i) to other forest landscapes in Sabah that include (or will include) protected forest reserves, and (ii) to other PA sub-systems in Sabah.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Sabah Forest Department investment in Class 1 forest reserve planning and management

baseline.comment: RM25 million for 58 Class I Protected Forest Reserves totalling 466,757 ha

target.comment: By end of Y5, the Sabah Forest Department investment in Class 1 forest is at least 25% more than the baseline

actual.comment: The financial assessment scorecard will be updated prior to the mid-term review of the project in 2016/2017.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: An enabling environment for optimized multiple use planning, financing, management and protection of forest landscapes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: State-level system for ensuring no net loss (NNL) of biodiversity from existing forest landscapes

baseline.comment: NNL is a new concept for Sabah

target.comment:
By end of Y2, state-level policies and regulations supporting NNL finalized
State-level NNL system in place by end of year 6 (Y6)
Amended to:
Pilot implementation of NNL (component 2) within project landscape provides initial practical lessons for drafting state-level policy
State level policy and regulation on NNL drafted in Y2
State-level NNL regulation in place by end of year 5 (Y5)

actual.comment:
The commitment to No Net Loss (NNL) within the project landscape has been reiterated and strengthened. So, besides actions taken as reported in 2014, the SFD has appointed Forest Trends to formulate a new forest policy in support of Output 1.1 of Component 1 of the project, that is, “new State-level policies and regulations for implementing no net loss (NNL)/net gain (NG) of biodiversity”.
So far, two reports have been produced and were presented by Forest Trends in the workshops. The second workshop, which was held on 16th June, 2015, Forest Trends presented the required policy changes and implementation structure for Sabah with regards to NNL/NG of biodiversity. The workshop recommended that the Sabah Forestry Department should undertake the land-use pilot project, the scoping study and net gain cost-benefit study. In addition, there was a proposal that the Government of Sabah should draft guidelines and a “roadmap” of the steps that would be needed to develop and put in place a regulatory NNL/NG system. These proposed supplementary studies and recommendations will be deliberated in the next Project Board meeting. In the meantime, Forest Trends will come up with the policy recommendations and guidelines on NNL/NG of biodiversity by December, 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: State-level policies and regulations for generating revenues from innovative financing mechanisms and re-investing into PA and sustainable multiple-use forest landscape planning and management

baseline.comment: No policies or regulations

target.comment: By end of Y5, new state-level policies and regulations in place for generating and reinvesting revenues from innovative financing mechanisms

actual.comment: Calling for consultancy service on this indicator/issue was made in May and again in July whereby a consultant "Green Spider" has been successfully appointed.The duration of the consultancy is four (4) years commencing in September, 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Capacities of staff within relevant state level Government departments (NROS, SEPU, SFD, YS, SBC, SWD, DID, EPD) to design, implement and manage / oversee biodiversity-friendly multiple-use, landscape-level forest management and sustainable financing schemes, and to monitor ecosystem service markets

baseline.comment: Limited capacities and experience of forest managers

target.comment: A 30% increase in multiple-use, landscape-level forestry, forest conservation and financial management capacities of SFD, NROS, SEPU,YS, DID, EPD

actual.comment: The next capacity development scorecard assessment will be done prior to the mid-term review in 2016. Individual capacity level will also be assessed.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Improved law enforcement effectiveness

baseline.comment: Law enforcement in the landscape is done by SFD and YS staff by means of mobile inspection and checkpoint at point of entry to the landscape.  There are 60 law enforcement staff and patrolling is conducted on a daily basis.  Of these 60, half have been awarded honorary wildlife warden status with powers of arrest. In 2010, there were less than five cases of fines.

target.comment:
Increase in the ratio of number of fines collected relative to law enforcement efforts.
Note: To be reviewed once information acquired.

actual.comment: The next assessment is due prior to the mid-term review in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Systems for compliance, monitoring and enforcement of multiple use forest regulations.

baseline.comment: Generic M&E guidelines, no training materials

target.comment: By end of project, a revised and updated set of regulations and guidelines for compliance monitoring and enforcement within a multiple use context that includes innovative revenue generating instruments

actual.comment:
In Progress. A sub-contract on “Ground Based Biodiversity Assessments (using a range of key taxa), Mapping & Monitoring Programmes (SC-6b)" has been given to Carnegie Institution for Science (USA) to further study on this issue. The duration of this contract is 4 years.
In addition, a consultancy on “Development of state-level policy options and mechanisms for payment for ecosystem services (SC – 2)" was advertised in early May, 2015. This consultancy services require the consultant to:
(i) Support the development of new State-level policies and regulations options and mechanisms/guidelines that regulate and govern biodiversity conservation and the application of financial mechanisms relating to Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) in Sabah; and
(ii) Develop a workable institutional framework to support a PES scheme in Sabah.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: State and national guidelines and operational policies for multiple-use forest landscape planning, management and conservation

baseline.comment: Sustainable Forest Management License Agreement (SFMLA)

target.comment: By end of Y3, policy and guidelines specific to multiple-use forest landscape established

actual.comment: This indicator would have to rely or has corresponding outputs from SC-6a (Landscape level biodiversity and forest quality assessment and mapping using LiDAR and hyperspectral imagery) and SC-6b [Ground-based biodiversity assessment (using a range of key taxa), mapping and monitoring programs] of which, these services will be carried out in 2016. This indicator also depends on the outcomes of the three consultancy services, that is, (i) SC-2 - Development of State-level policy options and mechanisms for PES; (ii) SC-3 - Development of international policy options and mechanisms for PES; and (iii) Policy and regulations assessment for implementing NNL/NG of biodiversity in sustainable multiple-use forest landscape Sabah - SC-1. All these consultancies are expected to commence during the last quarter of 2015.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Multiple-use forest landscape planning and management system demonstrated at pilot site

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Development of multiple-use forest landscape planning, management and conservation systems within project demonstration area

baseline.comment:
No multiple use planning, management or conservation systems in use at site
Fragmented and out-dated collection of forest data in EIA reports

target.comment:
By end of Y1, biodiversity overlay completed
By end of year 3, economic model selected and applied in landscape planning
By end of Y3, landscape-level management plan completed
Amended to:
By end of Y1, all existing management plans (to become sub-plans within new landscape framework) covering portions of the landscape have been collected and analyzed and priority gaps identified
By end of Y2, biodiversity overlay completed
By end of year 2, economic model selected and tested—annual refinement required
By end of Y3, landscape-level management plan completed

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Implementation of landscape-level management plan

baseline.comment: No plan / implementation

target.comment:
New PA established (ecological corridors, watershed, salt lick)
Sustainable-use management system based on sustainable off-take, no net loss, monitoring and enforcement
Amended to:
New PAs established (ecological corridors, watershed, salt lick) by end of year 3
Sustainable-use management system based on sustainable off-take, no net loss, monitoring and enforcement(especially of hunting)

actual.comment:
As mentioned earlier a large Class I Protection Forest Reserves and VJR have been gazetted within the project area.
The new Class I Protection Forest Reserves that have been gazetted on 24th December, 2014 are as follows:
i. Gunung Rara Wildlife Corridor F.R. - 10,364 ha; Wildlife Corridor
ii. Maliau Buffer Zone F.R. (Ext.) - 5,181 ha; Ecological and Wildlife Corridor
iii. Sg. Anjeranjermut F.R. - 3,857 ha; Ecological and Wildlife Corridor
iv. Sg. Sumagas F.R. - 4,215 ha; Salt Lick and Wildlife Corridor
v. Sg. Tiagau F.R. (Ext.) - 7,010ha; Wildlife Corridor and Water Catchment
The new VJR that has been gazetted on 24th December, 2014 is Sg. Imbak F.R. (Ext.) - 4,655 ha; Ecological
The Project will support management planning for these areas and other areas of different land uses.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Habitat conserved and degradation reduced under landscape - level management plan

baseline.comment: Forest plantation occupies 15% of total project landscape; baseline scenario to be determined as part of model development

target.comment:
Land use for agricultural production at least 60% lower compared with baseline scenario
Amended to: At a minimum, a large majority of the biodiversity losses expected under current scenario #2 will be avoided, mitigated and/or offset within the landscapes.

actual.comment: Based on the signed MoU between the SFD and UNDP, the land-use allocation for ITP or Agroforestry in the project area is 9,937 ha and for agriculture, the total gross area is 37,835.30 ha , that is, oilpalm plantations (35,878 ha) and organic agriculture (1,957.3 ha). This means that the total gross area for forest plantation and agriculture in the project area was reduced from 54,967 ha to 47,772.3 ha. The area will be further reduced assuming that only 70% of the gross area can be converted to oilpalm plantations, which means that a large majority of the biodiversity losses will be avoided, mitigated and/or offset within the landscape.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Sustainable financing of protected areas and associated forest landscape areas demonstrated at the pilot site

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Use of innovative revenue mechanisms for revenue-generating conservation

baseline.comment: Only revenue generation is from timber concessions; other ecosystem services remain un-monetized, leading to over-harvesting and/or inappropriate timber harvesting methods

target.comment:
By end of Y2, optimal landuse matrix, based on environmental economic considerations within project landscape, are determined
By end of project, three revenue generating mechanisms, including REDD+ / carbon, biodiversity offsets and PES, have been designed and piloted, with total annual revenues projected to reach at least 50% of optimal management costs within five years following project completion

actual.comment: An international consultancy to look for an Environmental Economist (IC - 3) has been advertised in May, 2015. The Environmental Economist is required, amongst others, to assess the total economic value of alternative land-use scenarios and ecosystems services. The Technical Evaluation Committee (TEC) had convened their meeting on 29th June, 2015 of which, their recommendations will be deliberated by the Project Board in their meeting, which is yet to be scheduled.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Management budgets, as % of optimal management costs

baseline.comment: RM11.4 million (2010) budget represents approximately 57% of optimal management costs (latter to be updated based on revised estimate of optimal management costs)

target.comment: Annual revenues available for sustainable, multiple use management and conservation equivalent to 80% of estimated optimal landscape level management costs and on upward trend

actual.comment: The next assessment will be conducted prior to the mid-term review of the project in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: An effective financial/ accounting system for fund management and disbursement

baseline.comment: Financial/accounting system at SFD and YS

target.comment:
Adaptive system in place by Y2
Amended to:
Adaptive system in place by Y2
Transparent mechanism that allows stakeholders to track revenue generated from proposed multiple-use activities in project site and the amount of each that is channeled back for conservation

actual.comment: A Financial Data Management Specialist consultancy service was advertised in May and July 2015. A consultant - Global Forestry Services (GFS) - was the successful tenderer. The consultancy period will be 16 working weeks within 12 months commencing in October, 2015.

iati-activity.title: Protected Area Financing in Malaysia
iati-activity.description: Enhancing Effectiveness and Financial Sustainability of Protected Area in Malaysia

iati-activity.title: Protected Area Financing
iati-activity.description: Enhancing Effectiveness and Financial Sustainability of Protected Area in Malaysia (PA)

result.title: Objective
result.description: To establish a performance-based financing structure to support effective Protected Area (PA) system management in Peninsular Malaysia

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Increase in the Federal Government investment in PA management

baseline.comment:
USD 7.25 million in 2010 for the DWNP, JNPC and PSPC
USD 6 million in 2011-2012 development budget under 10th Malaysia Plan

target.comment:
25% increase of operational budget in real terms for the 3 target PA networks based on aggregate funding from Federal and State Government source
25% increase in development budget under the 5-year Malaysia Plan

actual.comment:
Operating Budget: The total operating budget for the three PA networks for 2014 was US$10.87 million (~MYR35.0 million) - a 50% increase compared to the 2010 baseline at US$7.25 million. The breakdown of operating budget of each PA network as follows:
Department of Wildlife and National Park (DWNP) = US$7.69 million (MYR24.60 million)
Johor National Park Corporation (JNPC) = US$2.50 million (~MYR8.0 million)
Perak State Park Corporation (PSPC) = US$0.56 million (~MYR1.8 million)
Development Budget: In 2014, the total development budget allocated was US$17 million (~MYR54.5 million) - a 183% increase from baseline level of US$6 million. The surge is mainly due to the implementation of infrastructure development projects such as wildlife crossing bridge/underpass, wildlife conservation centres and jetty; habitat enrichment, wildlife survey and inventory, and wildlife conservation; which have been earmarked since year 2011 and 2013 – the first and second rolling plan of the 10th Malaysia Plan. The breakdown of development budget of each PA network as follows:
DWNP = US$5 million (MYR16 million)
JNPC = US$6.9 million (MYR22 million)
PSPC = US$5.1 million (MYR16.5 million)
Year 2014 exchange rate at US$1.00: MYR3.20 is used to make comparable budget trends instead of current exchange rate, which has seen Ringgit Malaysia depreciated significantly against US Dollar.
This positive trend reflected an increased government commitment in protected area under the business as usual scenario as the performance-based financing structure for protected area is yet to be established, piloted and institutionalized within the existing public finance and budgetary system.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Financial sustainability scorecard for the 3 PA networks
DWNP
JNPC
PSPC

actual.comment:
DWNP: 55.8%
JNPC: 44.7%
PSPC: 53.1%
Financial sustainability scorecards were completed in consultation with the three PA agencies and other key sub-national authorities in March and May 2015. Preliminary results were collated and shared with the agencies highlighting the need for supplementary data. Follow up meetings were held with each of the agencies to confirm and verify the final scores.
The financial sustainability scores for DWNP, JNPC and PSPC have recorded an increase, with PSPC exceeded the target level at end of project (50%). Part I of the financial sustainability scorecard reflects a gradual increase in budget allocation of the three PA networks. In 2014, all the PA networks benefitted from substantial increase in development budget allocation, mainly for the development of infrastructure beneficial to PA management such as roads (Endau Rompin), a jetty (Royal Belum) and other upkeep and maintenance works (DWNP). As these are one-off allocation, the figures can only be matched with PA networks continue to advocate for additional development budget through submission and approval of PA related project proposals that are in line with the development priorities of the 11th Malaysia Plan.
In terms of revenue generated from the PAs, Taman Negara National Park had a strong year buoyed by recognition of the 75th Anniversary of the Park's establishment. However, a devastating flood in the last quarter of 2014 in the park closure resulted in low visitor numbers from November 2014 to March 2015. Royal Belum State Park has demonstrated increased capacity to generate more revenue from visitors. Despide of the serious flooding experienced in December 2014, the Park's collection from entrance fees and recreational related charges was more than double the 2010 baseline. It has recorded steady visitor arrivals from Europe due to successful promotion in these high-value niche markets, thereby increasing revenue from tourism while upholding strong emphasis on conservation. PSPC’s higher score can be attributed to significant improvements in Part II which is a measure of capacity development for financial management and planning. This is a result of better understanding of the financial planning and management system in place which includes technical support from the Perak State Government. Adjustments were made to the Total Possible Score as several provisions were technically not applicable; this includes some of the revenue diversification mechanisms, which are currently not available and feasible. As the financial score for PSPC exceeds the end of project target level, it is recommended that a new target be set to provide scope for further improvement and benchmarking.
Overall, both JNPC and DWNP showed stronger financial sustainability scores, edging closer to the end of project target level. These stronger scores are also mainly attributed to improved scores in Part IIIn demonstrating improved capacity in planning and financial management. DWNP, for example has improved its financial data management to more accurately represent actual expenditure of PA management across the different states which was previously bundled with wildlife management costs.
All three PA agencies have much room for improvement in terms of enhancing their scores in Part III which deals with tools for revenue generation by PAs. Of the three, JNPC has made some progress towards diversifying its sources of revenue - a new Private Public Partnership (PPP) initiative at Pulau Kukup involving Iskandar Regional Development Authority and JNPC is currently being developed. If successful, this could present a new source of revenue for the JNPC’s PA network.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Systemic & Institutional Capacities to manage and financially support a national PA System

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Establishment of the policy framework for the National PA system

baseline.comment: No framework exists, resulting in a fragmented PA system with a large number of PAs gazetted under different acts based on varied management standards

target.comment: A single framework with clear categorisation of all the PAs in the PA Master List in Peninsular Malaysia, with uniform, accepted management standards and reporting requirements

actual.comment:
The project has improvised the initial plan of using PoWPA Action Plan as a platform to develop the National Framework for PA due to the process of finalizing the PoWPA Action Plan led by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE) is still on-going and yet to reach consensus among the key federal and state agencies.
The project has since taken a proactive approach by carried out consultations with key state governments including Sabah and Sarawak where some States have agreed in principle to develop a common National Framework, standard definition and management practices for PAs. A draft Terms of Reference (TOR) for national experts was initially developed in March 2015. Following consultation with DWNP and UNDP, the decision was made to engage two national experts to focus on two key areas: (i) Legal and Enabling Environment for Establishing a National Framework; and (ii) Basis and outline for the National Framework. The TORs have been prepared and they are now being finalized for advertisement in September 2015. It is expected that the National Framework to complete by end of 2016.
The on-going preparation of the Management and Business Plans for the three target PA sites also contributes to the development of National Framework for PA by drafting a common management and business plan template, which could form the basis of a common template for nationwide adoption. Key agencies will be invited to give their inputs to the prototype template to ensure its applicability in different PA contexts across the country.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Integrated PA information and performance monitoring system

baseline.comment: Neither performance criteria nor monitoring systems specific to PA management exist

target.comment: A national, integrated PA information system established with the primary function of PA performance monitoring, and decision support for relevant government bodies

actual.comment:
Data on PAs is fragmented and dispersed, the project has been identifying the best agency to host the database. Initial consultation with the Forest Institute of Malaysia (FRIM) which is responsible for updating and maintaining the National Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism [established in 2008] indicates their support for hosting a PA database within the CHM’s Biodiversity Database, which can support decision-making in the planning and management of PA. It is envisaged that the CHM can serve as an accessible and user-friendly platform for housing information on PAs in the country.
As an interim measure, the project is developing a PA profile template that captures essential management-oriented data and information of three target PA sites, and PAs within the three PA Networks. Having demonstrated the usefulness of this template for gathering and collating data on PAs, the project will seek cooperation of relevant PA agencies to complete the actual database which will ultimately resides with FRIM.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Financial incentive system, based primarily on performance indices, established and operational.

baseline.comment: No performance-linked financial incentive system exists.

target.comment: System established supporting a minimum of 866,000 ha of the PA estate

actual.comment:
The establishment of the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust in 2014 provides an opportunity to pilot the performance-based financing system for protected areas. As such, the project has developed governance structure and drafted the operating guidelines for the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund (NCTF) and submitted to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE).
The draft Operating Guidelines include general criteria for project selection, appropriate indicators, and M&E system but it does not specify PA related performance indicators for PA related projects/initiatives.
The Operating Guidelines were tabled at the first meeting of the NCTF Board held on 21 April 2015. There has been limited feedback received from NRE regarding the performance indicators for PA related project selection under the NCTF.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
National PA System mainstreamed in the budgeting process for 5-year Malaysia Plan
Increased number of â€œbankableâ€ projects in support of PA management approved for funding through operational grants.

baseline.comment: No budget line for PA management in Malaysia Plan. Currently the budgets for PA infrastructure development is determined based on individual requests from State governments with no systematic planning looking at conservation priorities of the national PA network as a whole.

target.comment:
Dedicated PA budget line in Malaysia Plan
Budgeting process of PA management/development is conducted based on increased levels of conservation priorities within the Federal and State funding system, using a range of tools including economic valuation results

actual.comment:
The 11th Malaysia Plan 2016 – 2020 (the 5-year development plan) was launched in May 2015 with six strategic thrusts, where Strategic Thrust 4 Pursuing Green Growth for Sustainability and Resilience has identified conservation of protected areas as one of the focus areas (Focus Area C: Strategy C1). The Focus Area A also includes a strategy on sustainable financing mechanisms such as green tax, carbon tax, REDD+, etc. Please refer to uploaded file on 11th Malaysia Plan and Strategy Paper 12.
The NRE provided its inputs into the 11th Malaysia Plan through the submission of a draft strategy paper on biodiversity and environmental management of project proposals for consideration under the 11th Malaysia Plan. Each of the three focal sites and their respective PA agencies have applied for budget allocations under the 11th Malaysia Plan.
There is no dedicated budget line for PA in 11th Malaysia Plan. The main criteria for all project selection including PA related projects is Creativity Index, where proposed projects need to demonstrate low cost and high impacts to income, cost of living, simplicity and convenience, health, safety & security, harmony, recreation and national pride, and environmental sustainability.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Technical and institutional capacities to manage sub-national PA networks, including capacities for effective financial management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Financing gap decreased by at least 25 % in the target PA sub-networks (PSPC, DWNP)

baseline.comment:
Current financing gaps based on regional benchmark of 196 staff per 1,000 km ² and US$ 1,000 per km ² are:
DWNP MYR8.69 million (US$2.90 million)
PSPC MYR2.12 million (US$0.71 million)

target.comment: An average 25% decrease in the financing gaps of the 3 PA sub- network agencies, in real terms through operationalisation of financial management and revenue diversification models across the sites.

actual.comment:
The business plans currently being developed with the project support will help to project the financial and capacity gaps at Taman Negara, Endau-Rompin and Royal Belum within Malaysian context. Efforts also being planned to undertake financial planning analysis at PA Networks level together with TEEB analysis. All the three PA Networks registered notable increase in year 2014 operating budget allocation compared to 2013.
The financing gaps are
DWNP: US$5.48 million (22% reduction from 2012 level)
PSPC: US$1.78 million (2% decrease from 2012 level).
In terms of development budget, in 2014 both networks PSPC and JNPC received additional allocation from the Federal Government for eco-tourism related infrastructure development.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Increase in capacity development indicator score (%) for three target sub-national PA networks
DWNP
JNPC
PSPC

target.comment:
An average 10% increase of the capacity development indicator score for each target sub-national PA networks.
70%
70%
55%

actual.comment:
Capacity scorecards for the three target sub-national PA networks was reviewed between March and May 2015. The scores obtained were as follows.
DWNP: 63.5%
JNPC: 63.5%
PSPC: 55.2%
JNPC's improved scores is mainly due to the following areas:
1. Strengthened legal capacity for enforcement arising from the revision of JNPC Enactment.
2. A total of 39 permanent posts had been approved for JNPC in 2014. As a result, 39 contract and daily paid staff will be upgraded to permanent positions in 2015. This is a significant development for ensuring job security and strengthening prospects for career development of protected area personnel.
PSPC has exceeded the end of project target level. Main improvements are stemmed from actions taken to strengthen the State Park Enactment to improve enforcement and penalties. In addition, cooperation between PSPC and other agencies (DWNP, State Forestry Department and the Royal Army Force) through the 1MBEON has helped to strengthen the enforcement operations of PAs. Efforts are being made to increase the number of staff positions in PSPC.
An Integrated Management Plan has been prepared by NCIA in 2012 covering 10 years. It covers some macro-level planning aspects for PSPC and has placed emphasis on Perak establishing itself as a major destination for ecotourism with Royal Belum being the jewel in the crown of its PA network. These developments are anticipated to lend support for the need to professionalise and strengthen effective management of the park. There is a stronger basis now to set a higher target for the remainder of the project period.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of PAs successfully meeting national management criteria and accessing performance-based financial transfers from the Federal system

baseline.comment: No baseline exists

target.comment: At least eight (8) among the terrestrial PAs over 20,000 ha under DWNP, JNPC and PSPC)

actual.comment: The national management criteria for performance-based financial transfers from federal to sub-national is yet to be established. It is expected to be pilot tested through the implementation of National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund by end of 2015. Application of performance monitoring and evaluation mechanism will be part of Trust Fund operationalization process. In addition, the development of management plans for the three target sites will provide important feedback to establishing the basis for national management criteria.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Economic and financial planning capacity institutionalized in the three sub-national PA network agencies

baseline.comment: There is minimal human capacity or institutional structure to address issues of financial sustainability.

target.comment: A unit is established in each of the sub-national PA agency dedicated to revenue diversification that will ensure financial sustainability

actual.comment:
In consultation with the three PA agencies, the project has ascertained that all agencies already have specific units in place that are responsible for financial planning. In view of this, it was recommended that the focus of the PA Financing project should be to enhance the skills for sustainable financial planning within these units. Current practices are mainly based on government budgetary allocations and there is limited focus at present on diversification of funding sources and ensuring performance-based financing. All Federal Ministries and agencies are expected to apply outcome-based budgeting in 2016/2017 onward.
The business plan development is expected to provide guidance and best practices to PA networks on potential mechanisms and modality for revenue diversification and sustainable financing mechanisms.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Coordination between the sub-PA network agencies

baseline.comment: Minimal coordination mechanisms

target.comment: Three agencies have common management approaches, PA performance monitoring mechanisms, and capacity development programmes.

actual.comment:
A stronger basis for standardizing approaches for PA management is being advanced through the project’s initiatives to build support for a common National Framework for PAs. In addition, these aspects are also expected to be enhanced through the development of a “standard template” for the PA management and business plan.
Through the transformation programme being implemented for the IBD, by October 2015 there will be a common national training platform for personnel from PA agencies. In addition, the project continues to facilitate training and exposure opportunities such as participation in the Korea Friendship Park Programme (2 participants, July 2015) and support for additional participants in the Advanced Training Course at the Wildlife Institute of India, Nov 2015.
To enhance coordination with PA agencies and state governments, the project coordinators at the state level are playing an active role and enabling the project to respond to needs identified by PA agencies. For 2015, an Interpretative Skills course has been developed for staff and local community at Endau Rompin National Park, while a learning and exchange activity is being planned for staff, government officers and community representatives from Taman Negara National Park.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Effective site-level PA management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of PAs successfully meeting national management criteria and accessing performance-based financial transfers from the Federal system

baseline.comment: No baseline exists

target.comment:
All 3 target PA sites have approved management and business / financing plans
20% increase in federal allocation of funding

actual.comment:
The development of management and business plan for the three sites commenced since January 2015. Two deliverables have been submitted namely, the gap analysis and stocktaking report. Standard template is being developed to describe key elements of a PA management and business plan and will be strengthened through stakeholder consultations.
Federal allocation for the sites in year 2014 are:
Taman Negara: MYR 12.6 million = US$ 3.94 million
Endau-Rompin: MYR 22.0 million = US$ 6.88 million
Royal Belum: MYR 16.5 million = US$ 5.16 million
Year 2014 exchange rate at US$1.00: MYR3.20 is used.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Improved management effectiveness as per METT scores for three target PAs.

baseline.comment:
METT scores in 2010:
Taman Negara - 74
Endau-Rompin 58
Royal Belum 53

target.comment:
Average 10% increase in METT scores for 3 target PAs
TN 82
ER NP 68
RB - 65

actual.comment:
METT scores for 2014:
Taman Negara NP – 74.5% (score 76)
Endau-Rompin NP – 59.8% (score 61)
Royal Belum SP– 66.7% (score 70)
The METT score for Taman Negara remained little changed at 74.5%. Generally, while the park scored well in terms of professional experience and capacity and having good systems and structure, it registered weaker scores associated with having adequate trained staff, equipment, technology and resources needed for effective management. Many tools and assets need to be upgraded to support park management needs. This is also in light of the increased threats associated with poaching activity within the park as well as higher risk of encroachment as land use change in converting the landscape surrounding the park from forest to plantations, roads and other uses.
The METT score for Endau Rompin registered a slight increase. The increase reflects some positive developments for capacity building for park staff, as well as strengthening research and monitoring via the MoA signed with Universiti Tun Hussein Onn. The Strategic Plan (“Pelan Perancangan Strategik” for 2012-2016 was reviewed in 2014 to and has been useful to strengthen Park management. However, the Park is hampered by the lack of a detailed Management and Business Plan and park staff are hampered in their ability to implement effective management due to resource and budget constraints. The increased exposure of park boundaries, roads and waterways to poachers is also an issue requiring urgent attention.
Royal Belum SP recorded a higher score of 70, exceeding the project target. This mainly reflects the strong institutional support from the state government for setting aside the State Park primarily as a PA for conservation. The state and PSPC have put in place the necessary legal and management processes for planning, management and reporting and planning, however effective management continues to be hampered by lack of human resources for various aspects including enforcement, research and monitoring, and community engagement.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase in gross revenue amount and revenue sources of the three demonstration PAs.

baseline.comment:
Taman Negara MYR 350,000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
Endau-Rompin National Park MYR 999,892 from entrance fees, tourism and recreational charges, income from concessions
Royal Belum State Park MYR 126,000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges

target.comment: 20% increase in gross revenue for the 3 target PA sites over the project period.

actual.comment:
Taman Negara National Park: MYR581,585 from entrance fees and recreational related charges; MYR152,577 is revenue from resort concessionaire at Kuala Tahan.
Endau-Rompin National Park: MYR820,955 from entrance fees, tourism and recreational charges, income from concessions.
Royal Belum State Park: MYR310,000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges.
Taman Negara National Park increased its collection in conjunction with the 75th Anniversary of the establishment of the Park. However, these gains were undercut by the impact of serious flooding which occurred in December 2014. The Project also produced a commemorative video and participated in an exhibition to help rekindle public interest in the Park.
Both Endau Rompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park were affected by the December floods which continues to affect visitors in 2015. Despite this, Royal Belum still managed to generate more than double its 2014 collection compared to the baseline. It has also recorded steady visitor arrivals from European visitors due to promotion strategies abroad. Endau Rompin NP recorded fewer visitor arrivals compared to the baseline. The park recently doubled its visitor fees for non-Malaysians, however, the impact of this is not evident as currently, Malaysians form the majority of the visitors to this park.
Taman Negara has plan to introduce a new fee structure. This is currently under the consideration of State Government of Pahang but the quantum and timeline for new structure is yet to be finalized. A revised fee structure was introduced at Endau-Rompin in 2013, which has a two tier fee rates for locals and foreigners. There are no plans yet for Royal Belum.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Length of park patrolled per year
Number of patrolling programmes per year
Percentage of the area patrolled per year
Number of patrolling staff
Number of illegal activity (including encroachment and poaching) cases within PA reported

baseline.comment:
Taman Negara: 5 10 km per day
Taman Negara: 8 - 10 days per month by walking
Taman Negara: 10%
Taman Negara: 2 cases in 2010

target.comment:
25% increase
50% increase
25% increase
50% increase

actual.comment:
In 2014, in addition to its regular patrols in Taman Negara, DWNP carried out 6 joint patrols with Malaysian Armed Forces under the 1MBEON (1Malaysia Biodiversity Enforcement Operation Network) Programme spearheaded by the government’s National Blue Ocean Strategy (NBOS). NBOS is a federal government approach to formulate high-impact, low-cost national strategies that are able to be rapidly executed, often combining and reallocating existing resources and capacities.The funds received by DWNP for this programme in 2014 was MYR570,000.
A total of 636 personnel were involved in these patrols: comprising 252 staff and 384 Army personnel.
Area covered in Taman Negara NP: 143,300 Ha or 33% of the total park area.
A total of 19 poachers were arrested and charged. Encroachment activities in the boundary of the Park were uncovered and halted.
The 1MBEON programme will continue in 2015 and will include Endau Rompin NP (3 joint patrols) and Royal Belum NP (3 joint patrols). There will again be six programmes in Taman Negara NP focussing on hotspot areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Tiger population as a flagship species in target PAs namely Taman Negara, Endau-Rompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park

baseline.comment:
Estimated tiger population for year 2013*:
Taman Negara: 18
Endau-Rompin National Park: XX
Royal Belum State Park: XX
*Estimated tiger population for the three target PAs for year 2013 will be used as baseline and the baseline figures will be indicated in the next Project Implementation Review 2013 2014.

target.comment: 50% increase in tiger population

actual.comment:
The official figure made public in 2014 is 250 – 340. This is based on field-based data gathered from seven known tiger ranging areas in Peninsula Malaysia. Estimates are based on camera trap surveys and field observation, mainly by Wildlife Conservation Society, DWNP and WWF Malaysia. Taman Negara, Endau-Rompin and Royal Belum among the seven areas studied. More studies are needed beyond these areas.
In order to obtain a reliable estimate for the whole country, it is important that additional forested areas are also studied. It remains difficult to estimate tiger population and compare data from previous years. A definitive comparison with previous estimates quoted in the baseline figure is not advisable as the previous method of data collection and extrapolation is different.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the conservation and sustainable use of biological and genetic resources in Malaysia through developing the national framework for the implementation of Access and Benefit Sharing under CBD

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National ABS law, regulations and institutional framework in place which will enable Malaysia to accede to the Nagoya Protocol

baseline.comment: No national law, regulations or operational institutional framework; state legislation on ABS only exists for Sabah and Sarawak

target.comment: National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by end of project and are applied by national and state Competent Authorities.

actual.comment: All stakeholders' consultations were completed - federal agencies, state agencies, research institutions, NGOs, Communities and private sectors. The draft Act is ready for submission in Parliament. However, at the moment the Attorney General's Office is finalising the incorporations of some final comments made by research institutions. NRE with the technical assistance of the Centre of Excellence of Biodiversity Law (CEBLAW) main focus in 2015 is to finalize the draft ABS bill and facilitate the process for the bill to be adopted by the Parliament in 2015. Fine-tuning of the draft ABS regulation will be conducted parallel to the process of finalizing the ABS draft Bill in the second half of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Financial and funding mechanism(s) for the management of ABS monetary benefits

baseline.comment: No mechanism exists

target.comment: Financial and funding mechanism(s) established and operational for the reinvestment of proceeds from ABS agreements into conservation

actual.comment: The terms of reference on the establishment of financial and funding mechanism for the management of ABS proceeds/monetary benefits has been prepared, reviewed and endorsed by the National Steering Committee meeting that met in May 2015. Such mechanism is needed to ensure monetary benefits are managed in a systematic way thereby implementing the overall objective for conservation.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: An operational national regulatory and institutional framework on ABS

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force

baseline.comment: No national law; state legislation on ABS only exists for Sabah and Sarawak

target.comment: National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by year 2

actual.comment: The draft ABS law has been fine-tuned based on inputs from the briefing held on 29 January 2015. A draft implementing regulation has been prepared and will be updated and consulted, following the same process of open consultation as the draft ABS national law.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: National and State Competent Authorities identified and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS

baseline.comment:
No national competent authority; state competent authorities only exist for Sabah and Sarawak[1].
[1] Sabah Biodiversity Centre; and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre and Sarawak Forestry Corporation.

target.comment: National and State Competent Authorities identified for all (13) States and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS by end of project

actual.comment:
Potential Competent Authorities (CAs) from all 13 states in Malaysia as well as some relevant federal ministries and agencies have been identified and are listed as Schedule 1 in the draft ABS law. The CAs identified are the Ministry of Federal Territories, state economic planning unit for the state of Kedah, Kelantan, Melaka, Johor, Pahang, Penang, Perak, Perlis, Selangor, Terengganu, Sabah Biodiversity Council and the Ministry Of Resource Planning And Environment Sarawak. CAs will be responsible to oversee ABS matters in state, especially in issuing access permit. In the process of obtaining and finalising the list of Competent Authorities from states and other ministry/agencies, briefings conducted on 5 March 2014 and 29 January 2015 have increased the understanding of ABS issues among states, the relevant ministries and agencies.
in all states has been identified and currently some form of awareness is being done especially to ensure the nominated CA knows their roles in implementing the regulations later.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources developed under the auspices of SaBC and used to inform national framework development

baseline.comment: No institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources exist for Malaysia

target.comment: Supportive institutional framework for sui generis systems for protecting traditional knowledge, innovations and practices and customary uses of biological resources developed forSabah State and used to inform national framework development.

actual.comment:
Sabah Biodiversity Council had given the approval for Sabah Biodiversity Centre (SaBC) to implement output 1.4 of the project on 26 February 2015. The Secretary of Natural Resources Office (NRO) has been appointed to chair the technical committee to monitor the implementation of the project.
The actual work for output 1.4 by SaBC has not commenced. The earlier proposed project by SaBC which is the development of a PIC communitty Protocol in Long Pasia, Sabah needs to be revisited and a discussion on this matter is planned in the second half of 2015. This is to ensure that the project contribute to the overall ABS national as well as the state's ABS processes.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Financial and funding mechanism(s) established at federal and state levels to receive and reinvest proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

baseline.comment: No formal governmental financial mechanism exists for reinvesting proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

target.comment: Financial and funding mechanism(s) established at federal and state levels by end of Year 3 to receive and reinvest proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

actual.comment: The TOR for the study on establishment of financial and funding mechanism to manage ABS proceeds (monetary benefits) has been developed, reviews, and endorsed in the National Steering Committee (NSC) meeting that met in May 2015. The study corresponds to the draft ABS law which include a provision that all monetary benefits where the Federal or state government is not the resource provider, may require some percentage of monetary benefits to be deposited into fund that maybe established by the federal or state government, to support conservation related activities.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Strengthened national institutional and stakeholder capacity for implementation of the national ABS framework

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Improved capacities of national and state competent authorities for ABS implementation as shown byan increase of at least 30% in thedraft ABS Capacity Development Scorecard

baseline.comment:
ABS Capacity Scorecard baselines :
NRE: 33%
Sabah: 35%
Sarawak: 31%
Other states: 0%
Other agencies:0%

target.comment:
ABS Capacity Scorecard targets:
NRE: 75%
Sabah: 75%
Sarawak: 75%
Other states: 30%
Other agencies: 30%

actual.comment: The next capacity scorecard assessment will be conducted before the mid-term review of the project in 2016. Upon the adoption of the draft national ABS bill in Cabinet and passing by the Parliament, NRE plans to conduct targeted capacity building to the identified CAs on how to deal with access application and monitoring compliance by user of biological resources. The capacity building or training to CAs (as the regulators) will be done based on a module that includes incorporating guidelines on mutually agreed terms and benefit sharing. The training for CAs is expected to be conducted by early 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of NCA, state and related agencies trained on ABS and bioprospecting related subjects to facilitate implementation of the national ABS framework. [1]

baseline.comment: No staff have been trained

target.comment: 100 staff from the NCA, 13 state CAs and related agencies (see footnote) are trained

actual.comment: No training has been conducted as the draft ABS law has not been passed (and so does the list of CAs named in the draft law). Training will be done based on a specific training module to CAs/regulators which is now under development and trainings are expected to be started in early 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Percentage of the population of researchers, local communities, and relevant industry targeted by the campaign is aware of the national law and CBD and NP provisions related to ABS and traditional knowledge (TK) among stakeholders including researchers, public, ILCs and industries[2]

actual.comment: The KAP study which is expected to commenced in July 2015 will produce the baseline on the awareness of stakeholders on the issue of ABS. The baseline is expected to be produced in November 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Best practice ABS processes (three) are demonstrated recognizing the principles of biodiversity conservation, Prior Informed Consent (PIC) and Mutually Agreed Terms (MAT) including the fair and equitable sharing of benefits.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

baseline.comment: No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements

target.comment: At least 2 ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

actual.comment:
The Forest Research Institute Malaysia (FRIM) and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre (SBC) are involved in implementing the pilot activities under outcome 3. FRIM's activities has been focused on documenting traditional knowledge from the Kintaq and Kensiu sub-ethnic in the state of Perak and Kedah. As of May 2015, 10 plant species that are picked based on their utilisation linked to traditional knowledge are now under lab examination for further screening to determine their biological compound, with the objective of deriving a nutraceutical/healthcare product to be commercialised.
SBC's planned pilot agreement will be done on plant based product derived from the Litsea cubeba plant, which produces fragrant oil that can be used in many personal care product. SBC is working very closely with the Lun bawang and Bidayuh Commuinty at Kg. Kiding. SBC is communicating with University of Portland, Oregon on conducting a feasibility study for Litsea based products to be marketed in the USA.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Number of PIC processes[1] with ILCs implemented in accordance with the planned PIC/community protocol
[1] These would be the processes leading up to the signing of ABS pilot agreements above.

baseline.comment: Some developmental work in Sabah and Sarawak on PIC processes

target.comment: At least 3 PIC processes with ILCs implemented in accordance with the planned PIC/community protocol

actual.comment: Since a standard prior informed consent protocol is not in place, FRIM is conducting their pilot project following their own PIC that observes the requirement of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). FRIM's has obtained the first level of PIC from Kintaq and Kensiu subethnic of which were to obtain their consent to participate in the TK documentation programme to identify potential products to be developed.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes disseminated at regional level

baseline.comment: Malaysia participates in UNEP-GEF ASEAN ABS project, but has limited experience to contribute to date

target.comment: Best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes presented at international workshop for ASEAN countries in Year 4, published in workshop proceedings and made available through NRE website

actual.comment: This output on sharing of best practices is envisaged to be implemented in the final year of the project where substantive project results and pilot agreements will be already in place.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of ABS agreements arising from the pilot projects that specify conservation measures to ensure the security of the concerned biological resources

baseline.comment: No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements or include specified conservation measures for related biological resources

target.comment: At least 2 ABS pilot agreements negotiated that, when necessary, include in situ and/or ex situ conservation measures to ensure the security of the concerned biological resources

actual.comment: No progress yet, expected to be completed by the final year of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: At least 80% of the population of ILCs participating in the pilot projects are aware of the existence, use and option values of the biological resources under their stewardship.

actual.comment: The KAP study will established the baseline on the awareness level of the selected stakeholders under the KAP survey. The result is expected to be presented in November 2015.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To increase federal and state level capacity to execute the CFSMP through the strengthening of institutional and operational structures and the piloting of sustainable forest landscape management plans in three tiger-priority landscapes, financed sustainably through the diversification of funding sources for conservation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Natural forest of 4 forest blocks of CFS (Main Range Forest Complex, South-east Pahang Peat Swamp Forest, Greater Taman Negara complex, Endau-Rompin-Sedili complex)

baseline.comment: 4.5 million ha of PRF and National Park in CFS complexes

target.comment: No net loss of forested area , with 95% remaining natural forest

actual.comment: Project is still in the inception phase from November 2014 to 30 June 2015. Activities of the project have not been carried out yet. The BII Technical Working Group (TWG) have started consultations to carry out the activities that relate to their outputs, including the involvement of taxonomists and stocktaking for both flora and fauna. Some stakeholders have suggested changes to the targets and discussions are ongoing.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Funds invested into CFS conservation (apart from GEF funds)

baseline.comment: Currently mostly government or ad hoc NGO funding

target.comment: CFS conservation fund receiving regular income through diverse sources

actual.comment: The government of Malaysia has set up a national Conservation Trust Fund with a seed fund of RM10 million. The project will support the operationalization of the trust fund for CFS activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Overall score of CFS Capacity Development Scorecard

baseline.comment: Current score is 12

target.comment: Score of at least 22 by project end

actual.comment: The next assessment will be conducted prior to the mid term review

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened institutional capacity of the Federal Government to oversee implementation of the CFSMP, ensuring compliance by sub-national actors, and monitoring impacts upon biodiversity, ecosystems and carbon stocks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Existence of environmental monitoring and management systems applicable to landscape management planning

baseline.comment: There are no effective mechanisms in place for incorporating biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks considerations into landscape management planning

target.comment: Environmental monitoring and management tools (developed under Outputs 1.1.1-1.1.4) are positioned for application in landscape management planning across the peninsula

actual.comment: Project is still in the inception phase from November 2014 to 30 June 2015. Activities of the project have not been carried out yet. The BII Technical Working Group (TWG) have started consultations to carry out the activities that relate to their outputs, including the involvement of taxonomists and stocktaking for both flora and fauna. Some stakeholders have suggested changes to the targets and discussions are ongoing.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: National CFS steering committee equipped to apply environmental monitoring and management tools in supervision of state level landscape management planning and monitoring of compliance to CFSMP

baseline.comment: National CFS steering committee has little knowledge on applications of environmental considerations in landscape management planning and monitoring

target.comment: National CFS steering committee is fully trained in the application of the tools (developed under Outputs 1.1.1-1.1.4) for supervision of state level landscape management planning and monitoring of compliance to CFSMP

actual.comment: The outputs for these are not carried out yet. This is expected to be done in year 3, after the tools are done between year 1 and year 3.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced wildlife crime law enforcement and wildlife monitoring capacity emplaced at national and state levels and in target forest landscapes to ensure reduction of wildlife and forestry crime

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Tiger populations in source PAs

baseline.comment: Estimated to be 0.3 individuals per 10,000 ha

target.comment: Population increased by at least 20%

actual.comment: The Wildlife Conservation TWG have completed discussions with stakeholders especially on tiger population targets & indicators. The TWG has decided to change the tiger population density from 0.3 individuals per 10,000 ha to 0.8 individuals per 100km2 based on recent studies by MYCAT and PERHILITAN. The tiger survey by respective organisations including WWF-M, PERHILITAN, and WCS is ongoing.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of recorded wildlife crime cases that are prosecuted and convicted in court

baseline.comment: Between 2011 and 2012, just 13% of cases recorded by DWNP were prosecuted in court

target.comment: At least 70% of recorded wildlife crime cases are prosecuted in court and given the legally stated penalty

actual.comment: To be gauged prior to the mid-term review.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Biodiversity and ecosystem service provision is mainstreamed in forest landscape management in the three priority landscapes via sustainable forest landscape management plans, resulting in maintained status of biodiversity and ecosystem services

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Multi-stakeholder landscape management plan implemented in each landscape, informed by biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks values

baseline.comment: Currently only Belum-Temengor has an integrated landscape management plan, formed without the use of environmental monitoring and management planning tools

target.comment: 693,500 ha across the three focal landscapes is under improved management incorporating environmental monitoring and management tools

actual.comment: In progress. The NSC was informed by the State governments that they will organise state level resources to facilitate identification, management and monitoring of all PLs and SLs while project activities are being implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: GEF Land Degradation-3 Tracking Tool score

baseline.comment: Currently a score of 5 out of a possible 10

target.comment: A score of at least 9 by end of project

actual.comment: In progress. Next assessment will be done prior to the mid-term review.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Status of biodiversity in the CFS

baseline.comment: The preliminary baseline BII lies between 48% and 68%; this will be refined at the start of the project building on PPG-stage analysis.

target.comment: BII of the CFS has not decreased below score at start of project

actual.comment: In progress. Next assessment will be done prior to the mid-term review. Related outputs for 2.1.1 and 2.1.3 which are carried out by FRIM are ongoing.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Corridor establishment increases connectivity of critical ecological linkages identified in the CFSMP and supports carbon emission avoidance and carbon sequestration under SFM practices

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: GEF SFM-REDD+ tracking tool

baseline.comment: Baseline score is 6 out of a possible 11

target.comment: Avoided emissions of 1.49 million tC due to 20,000 ha gazetted; 17,600tC/yr due to ARR activities in 4,000 ha; tracking tool score of at least 10

actual.comment: The Perak State government has gazetted around 19,000 ha along the Belum Temenggor Forest Complex as part of its commitment of CFS initiative.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Presence of wildlife in corridor areas

baseline.comment: Connectivity between forest patches is low and restricts wildlife movement, particularly in unprotected areas

target.comment: An additional 20,000 ha gazetted, 4,000 ha rehabilitated and wildlife crossings established encourage increased presence and movement of wildlife in these areas

actual.comment: In progress. Outputs related to 2.2.3 on wildlife crossing is ongoing and led by PERHILITAN

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: The socio-economic status of local communities improved and support for conservation increased through the generation of sustainable livelihoods based on wildlife, and the reduction of human-wildlife conflict

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Conservation-related livelihood activities involving both men and women established in pilot areas and making significant contributions to household income of Orang Asli participants

baseline.comment: Baseline household income gained from different livelihood activities (undertaken by both men and women) to be established at start of project, disaggregated by gender. Some craft groups exist in Belum-Temengor but have been given little support and opportunity to develop

target.comment: At least two ecotourism and handicrafts CBOs in operation, with proven engagement of both men and women, and increasing household income of participants by 25%

actual.comment: Outputs regarding 2.3.1 on ecotourism led by both FDPM and PERHILITAN is ongoing. In relation to this, the Johor TWG is in the process of being established with the involvement of DWNP and other relevant agencies. An elephant sanctuary is in the process of being gazetted.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of reported HWC incidences within communities, and level of economic loss for men, women and households in general

baseline.comment: In 2012, 111 wildlife complaints were recorded in Belum-Temengor; 19 complaints were recorded in Endau-Rompin. Baseline for economic losses to be established at start of project, disaggregated by gender

target.comment: Reports of HWC incidences reduced by 25% in target communities and economic losses reduced by 25%

actual.comment: Outcome to be expected in 2017

result.title: Outcome 6
result.description: The long term biodiversity and ecosystem conservation of the CFS is enhanced through the diversification of funding sources for conservation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: New and additional sources of funding for conservation in the CFS are in place (of at least $1 million by EoP) and functioning as reflected in BD-2 TT

baseline.comment: CFS conservation funding dependent on government budgets and NGO/donor projects

target.comment: Funds are regularly contributed towards CFS conservation through four separate streams under Outputs 3.1.1-3.1.4

actual.comment: In Progress. Output 3.1.1 and 3.1.3 are ongoing. The TWG in Forestry Department will work with Federal Economic Planning Unit and State Planning Units

result.title: Outcome 7
result.description: Funding allocations for biodiversity and ecosystem conservation in the CFS are secured and formalised

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Coordinated mechanism in place for attracting, earmarking and administering funding for biodiversity and ecosystem conservation in the CFS

baseline.comment: Fundraising and financial flows for conservation in the CFS largely uncoordinated between different agencies and organisations

target.comment: With significantly reduced dependence on funds from federal budgets and NGOs, the conservation of the CFS is directed and managed via the dedicated fund without influence of national economic circumstances

actual.comment: The TWG at the Forestry Department will keep track of this. Recent government approval of RM50 million for wildlife Survey is very encouraging

result.title: Outcome 8
result.description: Strategic planning processes in place and being used to link financing to conservation management needs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: CFS conservation management is supported by sustainable financing plans

baseline.comment: Budget preparation and planning in government conservation agencies largely delinked from CFS conservation management plans

target.comment: One CFS-wide and 3 state-level sustainable financing plans ensure that landscapes are managed sustainably, dependent in the long term on the values of their biodiversity and ecosystem services

actual.comment: Expected to be carried out in 2018.
